utterances: What's interesting is what's not in Congressman Ryan's plan.
There's no mention of the president's healthcare law.
And remember, that was the original reason for the government shutdown, Republicans' desire to defund Obamacare.
What Ryan suggests instead is some combination of changes to entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security to cut the deficit, and tax reform that he says would encourage economic growth.
Now, this is not the sweeping change to Medicare, the voucherization of that program that Congressman Ryan's proposed in the past.
Instead he's calling for more modest changes, some of which the president himself has put forward, although in Obama's blueprint, those changes are always accompanied by additional tax revenue.
And that's something that's missing from Congressman Ryan's plan.
Well, how is Congressman Ryan's article and his proposal being received?
Well, some of the most conservative Republicans are not ready to give up their attack on Obamacare yet.
They see that as an easier target than more established programs like Medicare or Social Security.
Republican House Speaker John Boehner appeared to throw those conservatives a bone this afternoon.
He went on the House floor and leveled a new attack on Obama's insurance exchanges, which went live just as the shutdown began and which continue to suffer from plenty of technical problems.
How can we tax people for not buying a product from a website that doesn't work?
How can you give big businesses a tax break and leave hardworking families out in the cold?
This is why we need to sit down and have a conversation about the big challenges that face our country.

What's interesting here is that Boehner starts out talking about Obamacare and within three sentences he shifts gears to talking about the big challenges that face our country, which might be the kinds of budget challenges that Ryan's talking about.

Leaders in the GOP recognize they're not likely to move the president on his signature healthcare law, but having shut down the government and rattled financial markets with the debt ceiling, they feel like they have to get something other than what Boehner calls unconditional surrender.

Well, Scott, looking ahead to that meeting tomorrow at the White House, the president and House Republicans, is that a suggestion that President Obama is abandoning or at least softening his no-negotiation stance?
Not necessarily, although the president will be meeting with a smaller group of Republicans than he hoped to.
He had wanted to invite all 232 House Republicans, which would've more like an audience than a negotiating session.
Instead, Speaker Boehner plans to bring a smaller party, fewer than 20.
He says a meeting like this is only worthwhile if it's focused on finding a solution.
White House spokesman Jay Carney repeated the president's message that he's happy to talk, but only after a couple of conditions have been met.
When it comes to our budget priorities, he has always been willing to negotiate, just not under the threat of shutdown or continued shutdown.
If Congress opens the government, if Congress raises the debt ceiling, then of course he'd be willing to sit down and negotiate with lawmakers over our budget priorities.
The group of Republicans headed to the White House does not include the most conservative lawmakers who pushed hardest for the shutdown.
But it doesn't include those who are most eager to reopen the government either.
Well, where do we go from here?
We might see some sort of short-term deal to buy time for more negotiation, 'cause the urgency is starting to build now.
This Friday will be the first federal payday when workers start missing paychecks - federal workers, that is.
And, of course, every passing day brings us closer to that debt ceiling deadline.
OK.
Thank you, Scott.
My pleasure, Robert.
That's NPR's Scott Horsley.
All this year, NPR is exploring spiritual music across America in a series called Ecstatic Voices.
Today's story takes us to New York City where the Renaissance Street Singers have been performing sacred music in public spaces for the last 40 years.
These singers insist their mission is not a religious one.
The group consists mostly of self-described atheists who nonetheless share a deep reverence for the hymns, psalms and motets of the 16th century, as NPR's Joel Rose reports.
Every other weekend, the Renaissance Street Singers come together on city sidewalks and train stations and public parks - anywhere they can find an audience.
(SOUNDBITE OF GROUP SINGING IN LATIN)
On this summer afternoon, 15 singers gather under a bridge in New York's Central Park.
They launched into a free two-hour concert of music by Palestrina, des Prez and other composers who lived more than 500 years ago.
(SOUNDBITE OF GROUP SINGING IN LATIN)
It's simple, ungussied music.
It's not anything showy.
It's just beautiful music.
John Hetland is the founder and director of the Renaissance Street Singers.
Hetland says he's loved this music ever since he was a child.
Hetland grew up in Wisconsin where his father was a Lutheran minister who taught his children to sing during long family car trips.

The predominant sense is that China and this trade war is like taking medicine - it's unpleasant in the short term, but it's good in the long term for China because it's forcing it to innovate and replace U.S.
goods, especially reliance in technology.
But China is also divided on whether they even want a trade deal.

I talked to people in the diplomatic corps and the economic ministries, and they're the ones who are really pushing for a trade deal as soon as possible to relieve the economic pressures that I just talked about.
But people in the defense ministries, in industrial policy, they say China should play hardball.
They see the U.S.
as an existential competitor who will find other ways to contain China, even if there is a trade deal.
But both sides say they don't trust the U.S.
as negotiating in good faith, and they're increasingly worried that, even if the U.S.
reaches a trade deal with China, that the U.S.
would not honor those terms.
So there's a lack of trust.
You just had the agreements that were reached in June that fell apart this past week.
So does anyone expect a new deal to come from the next round of talks?

Talks are happening in September, but optimism for those talks is pretty low right now, simply because there are just so many issues on the table that have yet to be addressed - issues like tech transfers and Chinese government subsidies.

But the stakes are pretty high because if there's no deal reached on September 1, President Trump has said there are going to be 10% tariffs on the remaining $300 billion of Chinese goods that have not yet been tariffed.
Chinese analysts here say that they're more optimistic there might be a deal before the U.S.
presidential election next year, though.
The hope is that President Trump is going to want some kind of trade victory to help his campaign.
That's NPR's Emily Feng in Beijing.
Thanks so much.
Thanks, Audie.
(SOUNDBITE OF CFCF'S ""AN IMPOSSIBLE CONDO"")
And now it's letter time.
Our editor Sasa Woodruff is here with me.
Hey, Sasa.
Hey, Farai.
How's it going?
I am doing fabulously.
So what are our folks saying this week?
We got some response from our reporters roundtable on Friday, when we discussed a bill that would help homeowners caught in the mortgage crisis.
Gretchen Zimmerman (ph), a homeowner in Vallejo, California, wrote in.
She says she understands from her own personal experience how people get stuck with mortgages that are more than their houses are worth.
I had a good job, good credit, and took out a normal loan.
I am upside down through no fault of my own with no bottom in sight.
I'm going to try to ride it out, but I'm not as bad off as many who bought when the market was higher.
These people are understandably considering cutting their losses.
Something does need to be done, or the U.S.
will end up in a depression.
Then, Rafi Garabidian(ph) from Berkley, California wrote in about our month-long series on jazz.
He was disappointed in a segment we did on women in jazz.
He wrote.

Today on your rather shallow interview with historian Linda Dahl, you skipped over one of the most famous, innovative musicians in the history of not just women players, but the whole jazz scene - Mary Lou Williams.
I am disappointed in this show, and this is why people do not know anything about this music.
Richard Karnatz(ph) of Texarkana, Texas responded to a segment we did on Monday about the gentrification of Harlem.
He wrote, ""should Harlem be kept for blacks?
If blacks are happy with their position in today's world, then I think it is a viable question to ask.

If, as some humans, they wish to improve their lot and become members of a society that is greater than the sum of its parts, the answer would have to be no. I was priced(ph) out of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, an area usually occupied by immigrants from Poland.
We didn't whine about rising prices, but sought greener pastures elsewhere.
Let the other homeowner take the price devaluation.
And finally, Chisabon Amayka(ph) wrote in last week while you were away.
She said, A very happy birthday to Mademoiselle Farai Chideya, whose program I have followed since I lived in Paris.
A reporter without equal, who runs a show as rich and provocative as it is serious and entertaining.
Over the course of her show, I find myself laughing, gasping, jotting notes, but mostly wishing Farai could afford her guests more time.
This is my one gripe with the show.
Some of the conversations are ended prematurely, which is such a shame.
Anyhow, best of luck to you and your phenomenal team.
Bravo to Tony Cox for his admirable stewardship in your absence.
Happy birthday, Farai, and good health to you, to keep producing this superb content.
Merci, merci.
Merci beaucoup for your birthday wishes.
It means a lot.
And we love getting everyone's letters.
Please keep your comments coming.

When you get there, you'll see lots of shows to choose from.
Make sure you pick News & Notes when you write to us.
And be sure to tell us where you're writing from and how to pronounce your name.
Thanks, Sasa.
No problem.
(Soundbite of music)
That's our show for today.
Thank you for sharing your time with us.
